Among the modes ‘quibus obligatio tollitur' described by Gaius ¹is the commencement os an action, litis contestatio, which, is the action were a iudicium legitimum, produced a quasi-novative effect, termed by the commentators novatio necessaria; the very delivery ol the formula in the action by the praetorto the iudex extinguished the defendant's debt, and substituted for it a new obligation, viz. the legal liability to be condemned if the plaintifi proved his ease, Gaius iii. 180, 181. It dis· iered, however, in its operation from novatio proper (novatio voluntaria), lor it leit the original obligation subsisting naturaliter, Dig. 12. 6. 60, and, as a consequence, did not destroy accessory rights, such as guaranties, hypotheca, etc, Dig. 46. 2. 29. 01 this process-consumption, as it is called, there are still traces in the Corpus iuris, but the general rule under Justinian is that litis contestatio no longer extinguishes the cre· ditor's right, Bk. iv. 13. 10 ins, Cod 3.1. 13. 2 and 5; 3.1o. npr. lt must indeed have ceased to extinguish it ipso iure with the disappearance of iudicia legitima under Diocletian, nn. 294 ; but now indeed it no longer enables it to be counteracted ope exceptionis; an obligatio is destroyed, not by the bringing oi an action, but only by its adjudication, so that we cease to read of the exceptio rei in iudicium deductae, which is swallowed up in the exceptio rei iudicatae, Dig. 9. 44. 3 ; 14 5. 4. 5: see on Bk. iv. 13. 5 int. Novatio necessaria is also said by Gaius to be ' produced by judgment, sententia, res iudicata; sor its effects, which do not belong here, see Poste's Gaius, p. 447.

Among modes of extinction operating ipso iure, which are not here noticed by Justinian, are physical impossibility of performance arising ex post iacto without default os the debtor, Dig. 46. 3. 92 ; ib. 98. 8; ib. 107: cs. note on Tit. 19. 1 supr. ; and in some cases death of one of the parties to the contract, as in societas (Tit. 25. 5 supr.) and mandatum, (Tit. 26. 10 supr.): cl. Gaius iii. 120, Dig. 4 8. 32. 3, and Bk. iv. 12. 1 ini, which is important sor a large class oi obligations arising ex delicto. The operation os compensatio (set-off) is a matter of some little difficulty: see on Bk. iv. 6. 30 ins.
